summary: Glioblastoma is the most aggressive and common type of primary brain cancer, originating from astrocytes. It is characterized by rapid growth, infiltrative nature, and a poor prognosis. Diagnosis is typically made through imaging (CT, MRI) and tissue biopsy, often with molecular characterization. Treatment involves a multimodal approach including surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy, with temozolomide being a common chemotherapeutic agent. Despite treatment, recurrence is frequent.
causes: Ionizing radiation exposure (including CT scan radiation)
Hereditary syndromes (e.g., neurofibromatosis, Li-Fraumeni syndrome, tuberous sclerosis, Turcot syndrome)
Infection with oncogenic CMV (potentially necessary for development)
Genetic alterations in RTK, PI3K/AKT/mTOR, p53, and RB pathways
risk_factors: Working in petroleum refining or rubber manufacturing
Exposure to SV40, HHV-6, and cytomegalovirus (CMV)
diagnosis: MRI scan (often appearing as ring-enhancing lesions)
Tissue biopsy (stereotactic biopsy or craniotomy with tumor resection)
Molecular characterization (e.g., IDH1/IDH2 mutation status, EGFR amplification, TERT promoter mutation, ATRX expression)
MR spectroscopy (for tumor metabolite concentration, e.g., increased choline peak)
treatments: High-dose steroids (e.g., dexamethasone) for swelling reduction
